bibl.title: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter and Joseph A. LePrince, February 15, 1916

div1.p: Carter and LePrince discuss a mosquito control project and the incidence of malaria to be expected.

div1.head: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter and Joseph A. LePrince, February 15, 1916
div1.p:
Nothing is advised to prevent the growth of aquatic plants which
in future may be a problem. This condition will have to be met when
it arises, if it does arise. We do not know enough of this yet to
advise general maneuvers in advance.

The measures we have indicated above are about all that are appli-
cable for the control of mosquito (Anopheles) production by this pond
within allowable economic limits. They are in excess of what we would
feel justified in requiring, but are as specified for the following
reasons:-

(1) The very considerable number of people who will be adjacent
to the pond at Whitney, Palmersville and Badin.

(2) The unusual risk of mosquito production entailed by the canal
and the bights behind the Winston-Salem R.R. track.

(3) The statement that you were prepared to carry out all meas-
ures which would do any good at any reasonable expense.

Even with these measures carried out it is not pretended that
there will be no anopheles production in the pond. There will be.
The total production of the pond site will likely be no greater or less
than at present, but the location of breeding will be changed, and ma-
laria may be increased in some places. The measures advised should,
however, minimize mosquito production and this with proper screening,
and possibly the use of quinine should minimize the malaria in the
community.

It must be noted that the increase in population adjacent to the
canal would increase the number of malaria cases among them, even with
no change in the condition of the breeding places. This increase will
be out of proportion to the increase in population, rather as a function
of the square, or possibly of the third power of that increase, and
Memo - 9
this must be discounted in estimating the malaria due directly to
mosquitoes produced in the pond. It will be the more noticeable as
people come in from non-malarious communities.
div1.closer:
(Signed) H. R. Carter
Asst. Surgeon Gen. U.S.P.H.S.
J. A. LePrince
Sanitary Engineer, U.S.P.H.S. 2/15/16
